trial_identification.studytitle: Sarcopenia (loss of muscle mass and function) and physical performance as predictors of clinical outcome in patients on dialysis
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A prospective longitudinal study investigating the effect of sarcopenia and physical performance on 9, 12 and 18 month morbidity and mortality in dialysis patients aged over 60 years.

interventions.interventions: Measurement of: - biochemical parameters by serum assay of albumin, haematocrit, urea, cholesterol, CRP, transferrin, TNF-alpha - muscle mass using a Fresenius bioimpedance spectrometer - muscle strength using Jamar hand dynamometer for grip strength and isometric muscle strength dynamometer for leg extension - functional muscle capacity using repeated chair stands, timed up-and-go, and 6 minute walk test - subjective nutritional status assessment using the validated "Subjective Global Analysis" questionnaire. Testing is performed during a single 45 minute assessment session at baseline, biochemical results are accessed from medical records, and TNF-alpha will be assayed from serum samples.
interventions.comparator: Comparison of mortality rates in moderately and severely sarcopenic patients vs non-sarcopenic patients.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Morbidity and all cause mortality as assessed by data linkage to medical records
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 9, 12 and 18 months after baseline data collection

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Morbidity and all cause mortality as assessed by data linkage to medical records
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 3 months after baseline clinical data collection

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Morbidity and all cause mortality as assessed by data linkage to medical records
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 months after baseline clinical data collection

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Cardiac pacemaker or implanted defibrillator Limb amputation

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A research study into how muscle bulk, strength and physical performance predict clinical outcomes in patients on dialysis. If the hypothesis proves to be correct, then these simple tests could be used when people are on dialysis or considering commencing dialysis. The results could highlight patients at increased risk of suffering medical complications during dialysis treatments.
